messages.text: Hi guys, quick question on basic sequential forward selection. Does that algorithm stops when performance starts to drop? For instance, if I specify _k=5_ (5 features to look for) and by adding the 4th feature the performance (e.g. some metrics such as accuracy) drops, will it stop or move forward?

messages.text:
Hi guys,

I am doing a Kruskal-wallis test and am wondering which post-hoc analysis is the most suitable for this? Been reading around and saw people recommend Dunn test. I am just wondering if there is any specific reason to not choosing something like Wilcoxon as they both non-parametric?

Thanks!

elements.text:
Hi guys,

I am doing a Kruskal-wallis test and am wondering which post-hoc analysis is the most suitable for this? Been reading around and saw people recommend Dunn test. I am just wondering if there is any specific reason to not choosing something like Wilcoxon as they both non-parametric?

Thanks!

messages.text:
I have a bit of an audit sampling conundrum, which isn't really my area of expertise, but one of those problems where I think I should definitely be a Bayesian so maybe someone here has ideas or pointers. I have a population of (let's say) 100,000 invoices, and want to answer the standard audit question "which fraction of these invoices is incorrect", for which a sample has to be audited. Now the standard approach would (probably) be to just specify some prior Beta distribution with "success" denoting an error found, and then work out how many samples I need (assuming a certain chance of drawing a success on each draw) to get to a posterior that gives the required confidence interval.

Now the twist is that I have a small (let's say 5%) subpopulation for which I know that the error rate is higher, and I wonder how (if at all) I should incorporate this knowledge:

* Just ignore it, the higher expected error rate in the subpopulation changes my expected whole population error rate and so the info is already in the sample calculation above;
* Treat them as two separate populations, which would likely lead to a higher overall sample size (as the whole population error rate is close to zero, removing the subpopulation will not really decrease the required sample size there, but a relatively large sample size will be required for the more volatile subpopulation)
* Something in between (I hear a lot about "pooling" estimators in Bayesian analysis, but it's one of these things I've never really got my traditional-econometrics-trained head around

I could imagine amending point (2) above in some way to basically calculate the sample size with reference to the whole population posterior, i.e. taking into account that the posterior for the subpopulation will be much less important when estimating the population posterior (which I guess would be a mixture of the two posteriors, weighted by the whole population share of both subpopulations?)

If anyone has any ideas on how to conceptually best approach this I'd be most grateful!

Now the twist is that I have a small (let's say 5%) subpopulation for which I know that the error rate is higher, and I wonder how (if at all) I should incorporate this knowledge:

* Just ignore it, the higher expected error rate in the subpopulation changes my expected whole population error rate and so the info is already in the sample calculation above;
* Treat them as two separate populations, which would likely lead to a higher overall sample size (as the whole population error rate is close to zero, removing the subpopulation will not really decrease the required sample size there, but a relatively large sample size will be required for the more volatile subpopulation)
* Something in between (I hear a lot about "pooling" estimators in Bayesian analysis, but it's one of these things I've never really got my traditional-econometrics-trained head around

I could imagine amending point (2) above in some way to basically calculate the sample size with reference to the whole population posterior, i.e. taking into account that the posterior for the subpopulation will be much less important when estimating the population posterior (which I guess would be a mixture of the two posteriors, weighted by the whole population share of both subpopulations?)

If anyone has any ideas on how to conceptually best approach this I'd be most grateful!

messages.text:
I have a basic stats question. So I am comparing a patient with a condition to the population of healthy. Due to only have 1 observation/patient, I am looking into the z-score, i.e. calculating that patient z-score based on healthy stats, to check how much it deviates to healthy central tendency and how significant it is (by converting it to p-value).

My questions:
1. Can this approach be called a 'one-sample z-test'? I have been reading around and most of the example I found, the 'one-sample' refers to another sample population, not 1 observation.
2. My follow-up question would be, is it valid to do multiple comparison correction, such as Bonferroni-Holm on top of this analysis?
I have been browsing about this but could not find any information for this specific question. Any help would be greatly appreciated!

elements.text:

Due to only have 1 observation/patient, I am looking into the z-score, i.e. calculating that patient z-score based on healthy stats, to check how much it deviates to healthy central tendency and how significant it is (by converting it to p-value).

My questions:
Can this approach be called a 'one-sample z-test'? I have been reading around and most of the example I found, the 'one-sample' refers to another sample population, not 1 observation.
My follow-up question would be, is it valid to do multiple comparison correction, such as Bonferroni-Holm on top of this analysis?
I have been browsing about this but could not find any information for this specific question. Any help would be greatly appreciated!

messages.text:
I have a question which is kind of a signal processing question. But I'm asking here because I know nothing about signal processing.

Let's say you have a sequence of ones and zeros. You think that every third entry in the sequence should be a one, and the rest zeros. You want to know if your observed sequence matches that pattern.

But there is some noise, and sometimes you get two ones in a row or three zeros in a row. But the sequence should "start back up again" after that error. So you can't just say "conditional on  `mod(obsnum, 3) == 0`, what is the probability of a `1`? Because if there is an errant `1` early in the sequence, your `mod(obsnum, 3)` rule is broken later on.

Is there some sort of statistic that allows me to say "on average, this one-third rule holds"?

messages.text:
I posted on StackExchange too!

<https://dsp.stackexchange.com/questions/74078/hypothesis-testing-with-binary-pattern>

It's a surprisingly interesting question. I didn't realize that in signal processing, noise comes in the form of flipped bits, not added ones and zeros. So heuristics from those problems don't apply easily.

messages.text:
The motivation is that there is a government agency that assigns "every third" person to a certain benefit. We want to know how well this rule is enforced or if we are really observing benefit eligibility in the right order, or if we are observing excess people or excess assignments. We think the "true" pattern is in our data set, but we also have junk in it. There is also uncertainty about which population this "every third rule" really applies to.

As we try to reverse engineer the exact workings of this "every third" rule, we need some metric to know how close we are to the ideal process.

elements.text:

We think the "true" pattern is in our data set, but we also have junk in it. There is also uncertainty about which population this "every third rule" really applies to.

As we try to reverse engineer the exact workings of this "every third" rule, we need some metric to know how close we are to the ideal process.

messages.text: so I would probably approach this differently...I don't know enough about the origin of the data, and won't ask more due to it being a gov't agency... But I'd treat this as a possible data quality issue. First I'd want to know things like "given a sample of 100 people who did/did not attend a benefit, how accurate is my data". Because there's multiple sources of error, there's reporting error and then there's the phenomena you actually care to investigate.

messages.text:
oooo okay I won't get nerd sniped on this but entropy could be your friend here. Maybe try measuring the overall entropy, and comparing it to the expected ideal sequences. Then sliding a window around to find "hot spots" where the entropy spikes drastically, and drilling down on those. Its interesting because you have degeneracy in your case for compliance.
Maybe this will provide inspiration for more rigor: <https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/4090616>

messages.text: Does anyone here have pointers on how to compare fixed effects between different generalized linear mixed effects models? I am planning to run two experiments that differ in one parameter, and I would like to fit a GLMM on each dataset. Then I want to compare if one or two fixed effects are significantly smaller in one model than in the other. The model specification should be the same for both models, but it will be two different sets of participants.

messages.text:
So I'm still noodling around with audit sampling, and have realised that it's actually quite a nice area in which to think about Bayesian stats for someone not used to it - maybe all the coinflip examples should be updated to be about audit sampling instead! I've written up a small example both to make sure I understand what's going on and to hopefully explain it to some colleagues that don't usually deal with statistics at all, and was wondering whether someone could give this a quick look to see whether I'm right.

The example is:
```r2d(x) = round(x, digits = 2)
i95(x) = "[$(r2d(quantile(x, 0.025))), $(r2d(quantile(x, 0.975)))]"
L_grid = 0:0.001:1

plot(Beta(5, 4), 
    label = "Prior (mean = $(r2d(mean(Beta(5, 4)))), 95% interval "*i95(Beta(5, 4))*")", 
        xlabel = "Population error rate (p)", ylabel = "Likelihood", format = :png, ylim = (-0.1, 4.8))
L = [pdf(Binomial(10, p), 3) for p ∈ L_grid]
L_lower95 = L_grid[findfirst(cumsum(L ./ sum(L)) .> 0.025)]
L_upper95 = L_grid[findfirst(cumsum(L ./ sum(L)) .> 0.975)]
plot!(L_grid, L, label = "Likelihood (mode = $(r2d(maximum(L))), 95% interval [$L_lower95, $L_upper95])")
plot!(Beta(8, 11), label = "Posterior (mean = $(r2d(mean(Beta(8, 11)))), 95% interval "*i95(Beta(8,11))*")")```
Which produces this plot:

messages.text: I've written some code that runs a bunch of linear models using `GLM.jl` and compares them. My code is painfully slow the first time it runs on new data, then pleasantly fast. It's like compilation cost, except that just changing the input data (not input types) to my function creates a slow down. Once the function has run on the data, it's fast. Does GLM have to compile something for every new formula it sees?

elements.text: I've written some code that runs a bunch of linear models using
GLM.jl

and compares them. My code is painfully slow the first time it runs on new data, then pleasantly fast. It's like compilation cost, except that just changing the input data (not input types) to my function creates a slow down. Once the function has run on the data, it's fast. Does GLM have to compile something for every new formula it sees?

messages.text:
My code looks roughly like
```function compare_regressions(y_col, x_dataframe)
    best_r2 = inf
    for (c1, c2) in all_pairs_distinct_except_y_col(cols(x_dataframe))
        train_df = df[:, [c1, c2]]
        rhs = Term(Symbol(c1)) + Term(Symbol(c2))
        reg_formula = Term(Symbol(y_col)) ~ ConstantTerm(1) + rhs
        model = lm(reg_formula, train_df)
        best_r2 = min(best_r2, r2(model))
    end
    return best_r2
end```

elements.text: My code looks roughly like

function compare_regressions(y_col, x_dataframe)
    best_r2 = inf
    for (c1, c2) in all_pairs_distinct_except_y_col(cols(x_dataframe))
        train_df = df[:, [c1, c2]]
        rhs = Term(Symbol(c1)) + Term(Symbol(c2))
        reg_formula = Term(Symbol(y_col)) ~ ConstantTerm(1) + rhs
        model = lm(reg_formula, train_df)
        best_r2 = min(best_r2, r2(model))
    end
    return best_r2
end

attachments.text: I recently stumbled on a package from @johnmyleswhite circa julia v0.3 that had some functionality I needed, though it hadn’t been updated for a while. It was a fairly simple code base, and I was able to get it working on julia v1.6. John doesn’t have time to maintain it, and he agreed that I could take it over, though I’m by no means an expert on this topic. Before I register it, I thought I’d post here for comments/suggestions. messages.text: just a heads up, there is a PR in ShiftedArrays (see <https://github.com/JuliaArrays/ShiftedArrays.jl/issues/39> and <https://github.com/JuliaArrays/ShiftedArrays.jl/pull/44>) to have `(Circ)ShiftedArray` throw out-of-bounds error if one tries to access and index outside of their axes (now it does not check for that). Just wanted to double check that Stats packages do not rely on accessing out-of-bounds indices (in any case, after the PR is merged, I will bump the major version number).

messages.text: If I have a unvariate continuous distribution `d` (from Distributions.jl) and a function `f` from R to R, what's the best way to get the mean of the random variable y = f(x)?

elements.text: If I have a unvariate continuous distribution
d
(from Distributions.jl) and a function
f
from R to R, what's the best way to get the mean of the random variable y = f(x)?

messages.text:
I thought I figured out a way to get what I wanted with Expectations.jl, but I run into trouble when trying to do the same thing with MonteCarloMeasurements.jl. So here is what I do so maybe someone with Statistics expertise can help me.

I have a random variable X defined by a normal distribution `dX = Normal(μ, σ)` and a simple function, say `f(x) = x^2 + 1` . That is, `f` is a simple parabola and is always > 0. I want a random variable Y that "multiplies" the PDF of X by this `f`. That is, I want the variable Y to have this PDF in Distributions.jl's lingo:
```pdf(dY, v) = pdf(dX, v) * f(v) / N```
where `dY` and `dX` are the distributions of Y and X, and `N = expectation(f, dX)` is there to normalize the RHS and ensure that this defines a valid PDF (I _think_ it works — feedback welcome!).
But I don't need to build the PDF of Y. Instead, to get the mean of Y, I did
```mean_Y = expectation(x -> x * f(x), dX) / expectation(f, dX)```
which I think is right (but would love some statistician check here).

I thought I could do all this using MonteCarloMeasurements.jl, starting from  `X = μ ± σ` for the random variable X, but then I'm not sure how get to the mean and variance that way. I expected
```Y = X * f(X) / mean(f(X))```
to work... But when I look at the plots of the PDF of Y as defined via `pdf(dY,v)` above and compare that to the histogram of the MonteCarloMeasurements-computed `Y` , I get widely differing distributions (although the means are almost identical)... Any tips for what I'm doing wrong?

messages.text:
Let me bake a MWE:
```using Distributions
using Plots
using Expectations
using MonteCarloMeasurements
μ, σ = 0.0, 1.0
dX = Normal(μ, σ)
f(x) = x^2 + 1
N = expectation(f, dX)
pdf_Y(v) = pdf(dX, v) * f(v) / N
X = μ ± σ
Y = X * f(X) / mean(f(X))
pltX = plot(x -> pdf(dX, x))
histogram!(pltX, X, normalize=true, α=0.3, title="A perfect match for X!")
pltY = plot(x -> pdf_Y(x))
histogram!(Y, normalize=true, α=0.3, title="No match for Y at all!")```
and attached two plots. What's wrong here for my two approaches to be so different? Is any of them correct?

elements.text: Let me bake a MWE:

using Distributions
using Plots
using Expectations
using MonteCarloMeasurements
μ, σ = 0.0, 1.0
dX = Normal(μ, σ)
f(x) = x^2 + 1
N = expectation(f, dX)
pdf_Y(v) = pdf(dX, v) * f(v) / N
X = μ ± σ
Y = X * f(X) / mean(f(X))
pltX = plot(x -> pdf(dX, x))
histogram!(pltX, X, normalize=true, α=0.3, title="A perfect match for X!")
pltY = plot(x -> pdf_Y(x))
histogram!(Y, normalize=true, α=0.3, title="No match for Y at all!")
and attached two plots. What's wrong here for my two approaches to be so different? Is any of them correct?

messages.text: <@UB197FRCL> just to be clear, are you aware that `pdf(dY, v) = pdf(dX, v) * f(v) / N` is not the pdf of `Y = f(X)`? Because it is a valid pdf indeed, but I'm not sure it's the one you are interested in, and it's definitely not the one of `Y`. If you are looking for the pdf/distrib of `Y = f(X)`, there is what <@U6C937ENB> said for the quadratic part of `f(x) = x^2 + 1` and in general where you're not lucky enough to land on a known distribution, you can just use any of the libraries that were already mentioned

messages.text: For simple cases (like the one you present here) you can try looking at the change of variable formula to try to figure out the density of your `Y`. But really, if it's just the expectation you are interested in, monte carlo libraries are just fine :slightly_smiling_face:
